Foreword

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) presents clear and robust conclusions in its global assessment of climate change science. The report confirms that human activity is the dominant cause of observed warming since the mid-20th century with 95% certainty. The climate system is warming, with many observed changes unprecedented over decades to millennia: warming of the atmosphere and the ocean, diminishing snow and ice, rising sea levels, and increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases. Each of the last three decades has been successively warmer at the Earth's surface than any preceding decade since 1850.

These findings confirm and enhance our scientific understanding of the climate system and the role of greenhouse gas emissions. The report demands the urgent attention of policymakers and the general public. The IPCC, jointly established by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) in 1988, has provided policymakers with authoritative and objective scientific and technical assessments.

This Working Group I contribution to the IPCC's Fifth Assessment Report contains new scientific knowledge that can be used to produce climate information and services to assist society in addressing the challenges of climate change. The timing is significant, as this information provides a new impetus to those responsible for concluding a new agreement under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in 2015.

Climate change is a long-term challenge that requires urgent action due to the pace and scale of greenhouse gas accumulation in the atmosphere and the risks of a more than 2°C temperature rise. We must focus on the fundamentals and take action to mitigate these risks, which will increase with every year.

This Working Group I assessment was made possible by the commitment and dedication of hundreds of experts worldwide, representing a wide range of disciplines. We express our gratitude to all authors, review editors, and expert reviewers for their contributions.
